name: César E. Chávez National Monument
description: Yes, we can! Widely recognized as the most important Latino leader in the United States during the twentieth century, Cesar Chavez led farm workers and supporters in the establishment of the country's first permanent agricultural union. His leadership brought sustained international attention to the plight of U.S. farm workers, and secured for them higher wages and safer working conditions.
shortDescription: Yes, we can! Widely recognized as the most important Latino leader in the United States during the twentieth century, Cesar Chavez led farm workers and supporters in the establishment of the country's...

operatingHours.description: The monument is open daily from 10:00 am to 4:00 pm except for the following holidays:  Easter Sunday, Thanksgiving Day and the Friday after, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and New Year's Eve and New Year's Day.

climate.weatherDescription: The climate in this area is mild, with warm, dry summers and cool winters. The Tehachapi Mountains are quite warm and sunny in summer, with temperatures typically around 90° F but occasionally exceeding 100° F during July, the warmest month. In winter, temperatures range between 30°-50° F. Frosty mornings are common, and roads may be icy. Before you visit, check the local weather forecast below. Weather can change rapidly.

images.title: Courtyard at Visitor Center Entrance
images.caption: A walkway separates the entrances to the visitor center and the memorial garden.

images.title: Memorial Garden & Gravesite
images.altText: Red roses bloom near a fountain and grave marker
images.caption: Roses grow in the memorial garden near the gravesite of César Chávez.

images.title: César Chávez's Office
images.altText: A chair and desk near bookshelves
images.caption: César Chávez's office was carefully preserved and can be seen in the exhibit hall.

images.title: Desert Garden
images.altText: Desert plants grow from rocky soil
images.caption: A desert garden features plants found in Yuma, Arizona, where César E. Chávez was born.

images.title: Photo Collection
images.altText: A black and white photo showing a farmworker demonstration
images.caption: In the exhibit hall, explore the history of the farmworker movement through photos taken during marches and strikes.

images.title: Naturalization Ceremony(2024) Man Awaiting For His Name
images.altText: A man watches a speaker up on a podium during a Naturalization Ceremony at Cesar E. Chavez National
images.caption: César E. Chávez National Monument and the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service’s (USCIS) Fresno Field Office presented a naturalization ceremony on March 31, 2024.

images.title: Anna's Hummingbird in the Garden
images.altText: A colorful hummingbird rests on a small branch.
images.caption: The Anna’s hummingbird, Calypte anna, is a medium to large hum­mingbird (10 cm; 4 in) that weighs about 2 pennies (4–4.5 g).

images.title: Decorative Fountain Outside the Entrance to the Chavez Memorial Garden
images.altText: A two-tiered fountain in front of a set of stairs that go up to an arbor.
images.caption: A decorative fountain stands outside the main entrance to the Chavez Memorial Garden.

images.title: Cesar Chavez Birthday Folklorico Dancing
images.altText: A set of folklorico dancers in traditional regalia dance together.
images.caption: Folklorico dancers perform in celebration of Cesar Chavez's birthday at the monument.

images.title: Ranger Leading Kids Back to the Memorial Garden
images.altText: A ranger leads a group of students down a path on the grounds of the Cesar Chavez National Monument.
images.caption: César E. Chávez National Monument is a great place for kids to learn about the legacy of one our nation's most important Latino leaders of the twentieth century. Activities include making buttons, guided ranger walks, and earning junior ranger badges.
